title: Democrats call for regular budget order
content:
Reid criticized House Republicans for not agreeing to a conference process yet . | JAY WESTCOTT/███ Dems call for regular budget order
Democrats have begun beating the drum that Republicans aren ’ t playing by the rules when it comes to negotiating a deal on the budget .
Citing Republican opposition as a major hurdle , Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid on Tuesday morning officially started the process of creating a budget conference committee with the House .
But the move to iron out the vast difference between the Senate and House budgets was objected to by Senate Republicans and remains in limbo .
Rep. Chris Van Hollen ( D-Md . ) , the ranking member of the House Budget Committee , will file a resolution in the House on Tuesday calling on House Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) to appoint conferees . In doing so , he criticized the House Republicans for obstructing regular order .
“ This comes from the party that insisted that Members of Congress not get paid unless each chamber passed a budget — it ’ s the height of hypocrisy , ” Van Hollen said . “ There is no time for delay . We must move forward immediately with a budget conference committee to work out our differences , boost job growth , and get our fiscal house in order . ”
Senate Budget Committee Chair Sen. Patty Murray ( D-Wash. ) said on Monday that she will meet with House Budget Chair Rep. Paul Ryan ( R-Wis. ) later this week to continue to discuss establishing a conference committee . Murray said she remains open to moving into a conference .
“ I ’ m optimistic that I ’ m trying as hard as I can , ” Murray told ███ .
Senate Democrats are grumbling increasingly loudly that Republicans aren ’ t playing ball in the budget process .
Under a “ regular order ” process , Reid and Boehner would name members to a conference that would meet to try to reach a compromise between the two budgets that were passed in late March .
On Tuesday morning , Reid criticized House Republicans for not agreeing to a conference process yet , saying after asking for “ regular order , ” the GOP was now resisting .
“ Strange thing happened — House Republicans did a complete 180 , they flipped , ” Reid said .
Reid said that House Republicans aren ’ t agreeing to move into a conference process “ for fear of a tea party revolt . ”
content_original:
Reid criticized House Republicans for not agreeing to a conference process yet. | JAY WESTCOTT/POLITICO Dems call for regular budget order

Democrats have begun beating the drum that Republicans aren’t playing by the rules when it comes to negotiating a deal on the budget.

Citing Republican opposition as a major hurdle, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid on Tuesday morning officially started the process of creating a budget conference committee with the House.

Story Continued Below

But the move to iron out the vast difference between the Senate and House budgets was objected to by Senate Republicans and remains in limbo.

Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), the ranking member of the House Budget Committee, will file a resolution in the House on Tuesday calling on House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) to appoint conferees. In doing so, he criticized the House Republicans for obstructing regular order.

“This comes from the party that insisted that Members of Congress not get paid unless each chamber passed a budget — it’s the height of hypocrisy,” Van Hollen said. “There is no time for delay. We must move forward immediately with a budget conference committee to work out our differences, boost job growth, and get our fiscal house in order.”

Senate Budget Committee Chair Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.) said on Monday that she will meet with House Budget Chair Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) later this week to continue to discuss establishing a conference committee . Murray said she remains open to moving into a conference.

“I’m optimistic that I’m trying as hard as I can,” Murray told POLITICO.

Senate Democrats are grumbling increasingly loudly that Republicans aren’t playing ball in the budget process.

Under a “regular order” process, Reid and Boehner would name members to a conference that would meet to try to reach a compromise between the two budgets that were passed in late March.

On Tuesday morning, Reid criticized House Republicans for not agreeing to a conference process yet, saying after asking for “regular order,” the GOP was now resisting.

“Strange thing happened — House Republicans did a complete 180, they flipped,” Reid said.

Reid said that House Republicans aren’t agreeing to move into a conference process “for fear of a tea party revolt.”
